name: Spark Spots: Inspirational Places to Work

text.text: Spark Spots: Inspirational Places to Work

There's a whole band of nomads out there in London trying to find a suitable spot to work in. And whilst cafes certainly do the job, sometimes you need a special environment to provoke those elusive sparks of genius. Or, equally as important, to give the impression that you're doing something super creative. Here are a selection of places to work in which are free (minus occasional coffee costs) including some beautiful libraries, creative cultural centres, tranquil bookshops and, of course, hotel lobbies.

tip.text:
Tucked away near Liverpool Street Station, this beautiful little library is the kind of place that's easily walked past. A welcome respite to the charged chaos outside, it has two rooms to work in which are quiet and spacious; it also comes with an ornate stained glass skylight. Magical. Not that many plug sockets though, so you might have to wrestle.

The library itself is like a time capsule of the Victorian age, with oak bookcases, flooring and cabinets galore, as well as big ol' bounded books that smell of times gone by. A great little spot to read a book, do some work, or just have a moment or two to yourself.

text.text: Tucked away near Liverpool Street Station, this beautiful little library is the kind of place that's easily walked past. A welcome respite to the charged chaos outside, it has two rooms to work in which are quiet and spacious; it also comes with an ornate stained glass skylight. Magical. Not that many plug sockets though, so you might have to wrestle.

tip.text:
The British Library is a huge, tranquil haven in the centre of manic London. With an enormous collections of ever-changing books, it's the perfect place to study. With a relaxing cafe on hand, this is the kinda place you can slump down in all day and seriously get your head down.

The 11 reading rooms get full pretty darn quickly but there are plenty of other spaces to work in and take advantage of the hushed sounds, the calming architecture and any literary treasures you fancy perusing. You need to register for a reader's pass the first time you go.

text.text: The iconic British Library might be a pretty obvious choice, but sometimes obvious things are good - like gender equality. The 11 reading rooms get full pretty darn quickly but there are plenty of other spaces to work in and take advantage of the hushed sounds, the calming architecture and any literary treasures you fancy perusing. You need to register for a reader's pass the first time you go.

listing.name: The National Art Library at V&A
listing.subtitle: Library & Art

tip.text:
Whilst the glorious V&A Cafe often gets plenty of attention, their National Art Library is a pretty ideal working spot. It's the kind of library all libraries want to be: a Grade II listed building with plenty of light, that authentic old book smell and traditional wooden workspaces. It's quiet â€” unless it's dissertation time â€” and you can also wonder around the spaces of the V&A when you hit that wall.

The collection of books housed in this sanctitude of learning is pretty darn impressive. Have a delve into the 1 million different books, journals and magazines they have there; you'll find hundreds of back-editions of Vogue, a copy of Shakespeare's First Folio or maybe even some 18th century chapbooks - if you're lucky that is.

text.text: Whilst the glorious V&A Cafe often gets plenty of attention, their National Art Library is a pretty ideal working spot. It's the kind of library all libraries want to be: a Grade II listed building with plenty of light, that authentic old book smell and traditional wooden workspaces. It's quiet â€” unless it's dissertation time â€” and you can also wonder around the spaces of the V&A when you hit that wall.

tip.text:
This is the kind of place that makes us wish we had four hands so we could give it four thumbs up. Set up at the bequeath of Sir Henry Wellcome, pharmaceutical entrepreneur, philanthropist and extremely wealthy man, this place carries on his good work by exploring the interconnections between science, art and life.

Not only does it put on super interesting free exhibitions, it has a strange and spacious library (with over 750,000 books), a big cafe and shop area, scientific oddities at every turn and lecture halls which host fascinating discussions. Running through everything they do here is the desire to have us reflecting on what it means to be human - and it really works. The curation is top notch and there's definitely a big budget to splurge with shows that are always startlingly high-tech and impressive.

text.text: We're big fans of the Wellcome Collection. Not only is it full of free super interesting science exhibitions about the body and mind, it also has a strange and spacious library perfect for coaxing out a little thought. After a fairly recent refurb, there is plenty of quirky furniture, medical books and scientific oddities to keep you entertained. Find yourself an alcove with some natural light and get to business.

tip.text:
Voted â€˜Londonâ€™s Ugliest Buildingâ€™ in a 2003 poll, it seems that we havenâ€™t been able to trust the British public long before the Brexit vote. This concrete Ziggurat is a mecca for all Brutalist architecture lovers, playing host to classical & contemporary music concerts, theatre performances, film screenings and art exhibitions. It also houses a humongous public library and a conservatory that is nothing short of a tropical oasis. Well, this is the largest arts centre in Europe we're talking about.

Have a mooch on in and be greeted to big industrial spaces equipped with high ceilings, artificial lighting, and the odd inconspicuous chair to sit back and absorb the raw ambience. Not the usual flouncy decoration, but they let their exhibitions do the talking. If youâ€™re under 25 be sure to sign up to their free Young Barbican membership programme, which knocks the price of their exhibitions and film screenings to Â£5. Donâ€™t say we donâ€™t look out for ya.

text.text: Europe's largest performing arts centre has got plenty of spaces to get a work on within its vast concrete walls. You could bop into the library and take advantage of the study spaces; you could cross the road and take a seat in the cosy surroundings of the Barbican Cinema Cafe; you could just drop your stuff anywhere you find a table and chair. It's free to work here and open until late. The Barbican conservatory also provides some welcome greenery if you need a break from the concrete.

tip.text:
After an 83 million pound conversion of the old Commonwealth Institute, we were expecting something pretty mind-altering with the new Design Museum. To be honest, we were slightly disappointed with the minimal, wood-focused design inside - perhaps it's supposed to be like a blank canvas? Anyhow, this is the world's leading museum when it comes to contemporary design. So put that in your pipe and smoke it.

It features two exhibition spaces, with shows typically costing around Â£15 . But there's also a free permanent collection which is a very visually engaging display running the rule on contemporary design. Along with that: a restaurant, design shop, library and studio. With regular talks and events, this is a hub of design activity and definitely worth visiting at least once.

text.text: If you need to come up with some fresh ideas, then we'd strongly recommend making an outing to the new Design Museum. You can work in either the cafe or the special library and archive, and the building itself â€” an Â£83 million conversion of the former Commonwealth building â€” is well worth a tour. Also, be sure to check their free permanent exhibition Designer Maker User, which is like a Science Museum for adults. The kind of inspiration that's almost certainly going to result in the best work you've ever done.

tip.text:
With its vast open spaces, plenty of light, numerous cafes and views of the Thames, The Southbank Centre has plenty going for it. It's certainly not the quietest of places but perhaps that general conversational hubbub is the kind of background noise you need to focus - have you ever even thought of that? There are a couple of libraries on site and you should find space here without too many problems.

While you're there, check out the Queen Elizabeth Hall roof garden. Alfresco bevs don't get more classy round these parts.

text.text: With its vast open spaces, plenty of light, numerous cafes and views of the Thames, The Southbank Centre has plenty going for it. It's certainly not the quietest of places but perhaps that general conversational hubbub is the kind of background noise you need to focus â€” have you ever even thought of that? There are a couple of libraries on site and you should find space here without too many problems.

tip.text:
Foyles is quite the institution, having been around for what can only be described as yonks. Equally iconic is Foyles cafe, which after a good rummage around the 5 different floors, can be a welcome sanctuary to sit back and take the weight off ya feet. It may not be the original cafe, and it may have taken on a more corporate, 'pls don't disturb I'm in a very important business meeting' vibe, but it's still Foyles cafe, and we still love it.

Diners can expect a constant stream of coffees, cakes and small meals throughout the day, served in a light & airy industrial space with exposed pipes and hanging lights. After a good refuelling session, what more is there to do than to jump back into that book scouring saddle.

text.text: Whilst any cafe in central London might do the job, Foyles definitely sets itself apart. That's mainly because it's located on top of a huge 5 floor bookshop which has, by our unscientific reckoning, every book ever written. There are some perfectly suitable shared workbenches to work on with views of the gallery below. Good food and good coffee is also...good.

tip.text:
Oh you just can't get more Shoreditch than the Ace Hotel. It's industrial, full of good looking young'uns furiously working away/hobnobbing at all hours, and there's always something new happening. In the lobby there's a bar whopping out cocktails, and another one in the basement that's open until 3am. The Hoi Polloi brasserie has a tidy menu of goodies all through the day, and up on the roof terrace they ship in DJs and curate exhibitions. This is definitely a place to be seen.

Brunch on the roof terrace? Don't mind if we do.

text.text: Alright alright, not everyone is going to find sitting in the lobby of the Ace Hotel that inspiring but we're including this place because when you're in there, slaving away along with loads of other similar sorts you might just feel part of a wave of creativity and all that. It's free, you can stay as long as you want and come any time you want. Often very busy, but those who get a seat cherish it.

Just like Ace Hotel and a bunch of other hotels offering the lobby/workspace thing, Holborn Hotel could be labelled an inspiring place due to the variety of characters you get filling the space, doing their shit and churning it out. You could be sitting next to the next Steve Jobs, the next Steve Austin, the next Steve Seagal. That's inspiration if ever we saw it.
